title: 114_hr3078
content: The "Commission on Americans Living Abroad Act of 2015" establishes a commission known as the "Commission on Americans Living Abroad" with defined membership. The Commission on Americans Living Abroad Act of 2015 establishes a 10-member Commission appointed by the President, with specific recommendations from leaders in the House and Senate. Not more than 6 members can be officers or employees of the United States, and political party affiliation is also limited to 6 members. The Commission on Americans Living Abroad Act of 2015 establishes a 10-member Commission appointed by the President, with specific recommendations from leaders in the House and Senate. Not more than 6 members can be of the same political party, and expertise requirements vary for officers/employees of the United States and other members. The Commission on Americans Living Abroad Act of 2015 establishes a 10-member Commission appointed for life by the President, with expertise requirements for members. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Commission must hold its first meeting within 60 days of all members being appointed. Meetings are called by the Chairperson, and a majority of members constitute a quorum. The President appoints a 10-member Commission on Americans Living Abroad Act of 2015. A majority of members form a quorum, and the President selects a Chairperson from among them. SEC. 4. DUTIES. The Commission will conduct a study on how Federal laws and policies impact US citizens living abroad, including financial reporting requirements and access to financial institutions. Chapter 4 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, also known as the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act, and requirements under the USA Patriot Act affect financial institutions. Federal requirements for family members of US citizens living abroad to become citizens and the voting process for US citizens living overseas are also addressed. The Commission conducting a study on US citizens living abroad will consult with organizations representing them and submit a report within a year. The study includes topics such as voting processes, interactions with Federal programs, jurisdiction of Federal agencies, and collaboration methods. The Commission conducting a study on US citizens living abroad will submit a report to the President, Congress, and relevant Federal agencies with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions. An update will be provided within one year detailing any actions taken by Federal agencies based on the recommendations. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission, as outlined in Section 5, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain necessary information from federal departments or agencies to carry out its duties. Members and agents of the Commission can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can use the United States mails like other government entities. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission will be compensated based on the Executive Schedule level IV rate for each day of duty. Officers or employees of the United States serving on the Commission will not receive additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, will be provided to Commission members at authorized rates. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The compensation for these positions can be determined by the Chairperson without adhering to specific regulations. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel with pay rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. The Federal Agency must respond to Commission recommendations within 180 days. The Commission will terminate upon submitting its update. $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2015 and 2016 for Commission operations.
